item.description:
tiany's Blog https://windytiany.github.io/posts/post4/ -

Notice: the note only contains the part 1 of the specialization.

Regression

Model

$f(\overrightarrow x)=\overrightarrow w\cdot\overrightarrow x+b=w_1x_1+w_2x_2+…+w_nx_n+b$

Terminology

$\overrightarrow x$: features.(It can be scalar if there is only one feature)

$y$: the output.(given by dataset)

$m$: the number of trianing examples.

n: the number of features.

$x^{(i)}, y^{(i)}$: the $i$th trianing example.

$f(x), \hat y$: the estimated value of y.

$\overrightarrow w, b$: parameters of the model.

Cost function

$J(\overrightarrow w, b) = {1\over2m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)}) - y^{(i)})^2$

def compute_cost(X, y, w, b):
    total_cost = 0

    for i in range(m):
        total_cost += (np.dot(X[i], w) + b - y[i]) ** 2
    total_cost /= 2 * m

    return total_cost

Gradient descent

calculate gradient

for w:

${\partial J(\overrightarrow w, b)\over\partial w_j}={1\over m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})x_j^{(i)}$

for b:

${\partial J(\overrightarrow w, b)\over\partial b}={1\over m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})$

update

$w_j=w_j-\alpha{1\over m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})x_j^{(i)}$

$b=b-\alpha{1\over m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})$

($\alpha$ is learning rate chosen by yourself)

(update these parameters simultaneously)

def calculate_gradient(X, y, w, b):
    dj_dw = np.zeros(n)
    dj_db = 0

    for i in range(m):
        dj_dw += (np.dot(X[i], w) + b - y[i]) * X[i]
        dj_db += np.dot(X[i], w) + b - y[i]

    dj_dw /= m
    dj_db /= m

    return dj_dw, dj_db



def gradient_descent(X, y, w, b, alpha=0.01, iterations=100000):
    while iterations:
        dj_dw, dj_db = calculate_gradient(X, y, w, b)
        w = w - alpha * dj_dw
        b = b - alpha * dj_db

        iteration -= 1

    return w, b

Binary classificaiton

the algorithm is called logistic regression, but it has no relation with Regression problems.

Model

sigmoid function

$f(z)={1\over{1+e^{-z}}}$

logistic regression model

$f(\overrightarrow x)={1\over{1+e^{-(\overrightarrow w\cdot\overrightarrow x+b)}}}$

def sigmoid(z):
    return 1 / (1 + np.exp(-z))

Cost function

loss function

$loss=-y^{(i)}log(f(x^{(i)}))-(1-y^{(i)})log(1-f(x^{(i)}))$

cost function

$J(\overrightarrow w, b)={1\over m}\sum_{i=1}^mloss$

The loss function is simplified by the following formula:

$$ loss= \begin{cases} -log(1-f(x^{(i)}))& when&y^{(i)}=0 \\ -log(f(x^{(i)}))& when&y^{(i)}=1 \end{cases} $$

Why this function?

$when\space y^{(i)}=0,\space if\space f(x^{(i)})\rightarrow0, loss\rightarrow0$

$when\space y^{(i)}=0,\space if\space f(x^{(i)})\rightarrow1, loss\rightarrow\infty$

$when\space y^{(i)}=1,\space if\space f(x^{(i)})\rightarrow0, loss\rightarrow\infty$

$when\space y^{(i)}=1,\space if\space f(x^{(i)})\rightarrow1, loss\rightarrow0$

def compute_cost(X, y, w, b):
    cost = 0

    for i in range(m):
        z_i = np.dot(X[i], w) + b
        f_i = sigmoid(z_i)
        loss = -y[i] * np.log(f_i) - (1-y[i]) * np.log(1-f_i)
        cost += loss
    
    cost /= m

    return cost

Gradient descent

calculate gradient

for w:

${\partial J(\overrightarrow w, b)\over\partial w_j}={1\over m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})x_j^{(i)}$

for b:

${\partial J(\overrightarrow w, b)\over\partial b}={1\over m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})$

update

$w_j=w_j-\alpha{1\over m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})x_j^{(i)}$

$b=b-\alpha{1\over m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})$

(alpha is learning rate chosen by yourself)

(update these parameters simultaneously)

def calculate_gradient(X, y, w, b):
    dj_dw = np.zeros(n)
    dj_db = 0

    for i in range(m):
        z_i = np.dot(X[i], w) + b
        f_i = sigmoid(z_i)
        dj_dw += (f_i - y[i]) * X[i]
        dj_db += f_i - y[i]

    dj_dw /= m
    dj_db /= m

    return dj_dw, dj_db



def gradient_descent(X, y, w, b, alpha=0.01, iterations=100000):
    while iterations:
        dj_dw, dj_db = calculate_gradient(X, y, w, b)
        w = w - alpha * dj_dw
        b = b - alpha * dj_db

        iteration -= 1

    return w, b

Improvement

Feature Scaling

This method is to reduce the range of features so the algorithm can be implemented efficiently.

Way 1:

$x_j = {x_j\over{max(x_j)}}$

Way 2: Mean normalization

$x_j={x_j-\mu_j\over{max(x_j)-min(x_j)}}$

($\mu_j$ is the mean of all $x_j$)

Way 3: Z-score normalization

$x_j={x_j-\mu_j\over\sigma_j}$

($\sigma_j$ is standard deviation)

# Z-score normalization
def Z_score_normalization(X):
    mu = np.mean(X, axis=0)
    sigma = np.std(X, axis=0)
    X = (X - mu) / sigma
    return X

Feature Engineering

This method can be used in polynomial regression. For example, you can create a new feature which is equal to square of the original features. Then, you can take this feature and run gradient descent. At last, you may get a non-linear model.

Regularization

This method is to solve the problem of overfitting.

Regression

regularized cost function

$J(\overrightarrow w, b)={1\over2m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)}) - y^{(i)})^2+{\lambda\over2m}\sum_{j=1}^nw_j^2$

regularized gradient

for w:

${\partial J(\overrightarrow w, b)\over\partial w_j}={1\over m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})x_j^{(i)}+{\lambda\over m}w_j$

for b:(there is no change)

${\partial J(\overrightarrow w, b)\over\partial b}={1\over m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})$

def compute_regularized_cost(X, y, w, b, _lambda=1):
    total_cost = 0

    for i in range(m):
        total_cost += (np.dot(X[i], w) + b - y[i]) ** 2
    total_cost /= 2 * m
    total_cost += _lambda * np.dot(w, w) / (2 * m)

    return total_cost


def compute_regularized_gradient(X, y, w, b, _lambda=1):
    dj_dw = np.zeros(n)
    dj_db = 0
    
    for i in range(m):
        dj_dw += (np.dot(X[i], w) + b - y[i]) * X[i]
        dj_db += np.dot(X[i], w) + b - y[i]
    dj_dw /= m
    dj_db /= m
    dj_dw += _lambda * w / m

    return dj_dw, dj_db
Binary Classification

regularized cost function

$J(\overrightarrow w, b)={1\over m}\sum_{i=1}^m[-y^{(i)}log(f(x^{(i)}))-(1-y^{(i)})log(1-f(x^{(i)}))]+{\lambda\over2m}\sum_{j=1}^nw_j^2$

regularized gradient

for w:

${\partial J(\overrightarrow w, b)\over\partial w_j}={1\over m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})x_j^{(i)}+{\lambda\over m}w_j$

for b:(there is no change)

${\partial J(\overrightarrow w, b)\over\partial b}={1\over m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})$

def compute_regularized_cost(X, y, w, b, _lambda=1):
    total_cost = 0

    for i in range(m):
        err_i = np.dot(X[i], w) + b
        f_i = sigmoid(z_i)
        loss = -y[i] * np.log(f_i) - (1-y[i]) * np.log(1-f_i)
        total_cost += loss
    total_cost /= m
    total_cost += _lambda * np.dot(w, w) / (2 * m)

    return total_cost


def compute_regularized_gradient(X, y, w, b, _lambda=1):
    dj_dw = np.zeros(n)
    dj_db = 0

    for i in range(m):
        err_i = np.dot(X[i], w) + b
        f_i = sigmoid(z_i)
        dj_dw += (f_i - y[i]) * X[i]
        dj_db += f_i - y[i]
    dj_dw /= m
    dj_db /= m
    dj_dw += _lambda * w / m

    return dj_dw, dj_db

Use scikit-learn

from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression, SGDRegressor, LogisticRegression
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler

#create Linear Regression model
linear_model = LinearRegression()
#X must be a 2-D Matrix to fit the model
linear_model.fit(X_train.reshape(-1, 1), y_train) 
#view parameters
b = linear_model.intercept_
w = linear_model.coef_
#make prediction
y_pred = linear_model.predict(X_train.reshape(-1, 1))
#---------------------------------------------------------------------
#feature scaling(Z-score normalization)
scaler = StandardScaler()
X_norm = scaler.fit_transform(X_train)
#create and fit a gradient descent regression model
sgdr = SGDRegressor(max_iter=1000)
sgdr.fit(X_norm, y_train)
#view parameters
b_norm = sgdr.intercept_
w_norm = sgdr.coef_
#make prediction
y_pred_sgd = sgdr.predict(X_norm)
#---------------------------------------------------------------------
#create and fit a Logistic Regression model
lr_model = LogisticRegression()
lr_model.fit(X, y)
#make prediction
y_pred = lr_model.predict(X)
#calculate accuracy
print(lr_model.score(X, y))

item.title: Build your blog by Hugo + Github Pages
item.description:
tiany's Blog https://windytiany.github.io/posts/post1/ -

0 Foreword

This is my first blog and I want to record the process I build this blog site on Windows.

1 Prerequisites

First, you need to download/install the following:

Go

Git

Hugo

Please add them to environment variables.

You can check using the following commands:

go version
git version
hugo version

2 Build your site

2.1 generate folder

Run the following command:

hugo new site my_blog

It would generate a folder named my_blog in current directory and the following are the functions of these files/folders:

  • config.toml : the configuration file.

  • content : stores all the content of the website, including all of your blog posts, resumes and so on, can include folders, but usually all.mdfiles.

  • static : stores static files such as your background pictures, logos, css, js, etc. The files in this directory will be directly copied to it/public. This folder has higher priority than the/staticfolder under the theme.

  • themes : stores all the themes downloaded and you can choose the theme by editing config file.

  • archetypes : stored.mdtemplate files, it has higher priority than/archetypesfolders under the theme.

  • data : stores data files for template calls.

  • layouts : store.htmltemplates, this folder has higher priority than/layoutsfolders under the theme.

  • public : After executing thehugocommand, store the generated static file.

2.2 download and use theme

You can go to this site to find themes. My blog uses diary so I’ll take it as an example.

cd my_blog
cd themes
git clone https://github.com/AmazingRise/hugo-theme-diary

These commands would download the theme into themes folder. To use it, you can open config.toml, and add:

theme = 'diary'

Save it, and run:

hugo server

Open http://127.0.0.1:1313, you can see that the theme is used.

2.3 write an article
cd my_blog
hugo new posts/post1.md

It would generate a file called post1.md. Open it, set draft to be false. Below that, you can write your article using Markdown.

Save it and run the server, you can see your article now!

3 Deploy your site on Github Pages

  1. Firstly, you should register a github account.

  2. Open your home page, click “+”, and then click “new repository”. The name should be like “username.github.io”, then click “create repository”.

  3. cd my_blog
hugo
cd public 
git init
git add .
git remote add origin https://github.com/username/username.github.io.git
git commit -m "first commit"
git push origin master

These commands would build your site and send them to github.

4. Open your repository, click “settings”, open “Pages”, click the link and that’s your website!

If you want to update your blog, run the following commands:

cd my_blog
hugo
cd public 
git init
git add .
git commit -m "update"
git push origin master
